steps.title: Start with a ripe pineapple that's more yellow than green.
steps.content: Start with a ripe pineapple that's more yellow than green. Press into the pineapple gently to feel if the fruit yields under your finger. Then, smell the base of the pineapple to tell if it's fragrant and sweet. If you can't smell the pineapple at all, it's not ripe enough. [1] X Research source If you're using a plastic cutting board, lay a kitchen towel underneath it to prevent the board from sliding around as you cut.

steps.title: Lay the pineapple on its side and slice off the crown 1⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) below the leaves.
steps.content: Lay the pineapple on its side and slice off the crown 1 ⁄ 2 inch (1.3 cm) below the leaves. [2] X Expert Source Ed Kuoha Chef Expert Interview. 9 November 2021. Hold the pineapple against the cutting board with your non-dominant hand and keep your fingers curled under so you don't accidentally cut them. Use a large knife to carefully slice off the end with the prickly leaves. The leaves are called the crown. [3] X Research source Use a chef's knife or serrated bread knife.

steps.title: Slice off the bottom of the pineapple so the fruit could sit flat.
steps.content: Slice off the bottom of the pineapple so the fruit could sit flat. Turn the pineapple 180-degrees and hold it in place with your non-dominant hand. Cut the base of the pineapple off so you remove the bottom 1 ⁄ 2 inch (1.3 cm). [4] X Expert Source Ed Kuoha Chef Expert Interview. 9 November 2021. The pineapple will now sit flat on its bottom so it will be easier to peel the sides.

steps.title: Turn the pineapple upright and place a knife near the top edge.
steps.content: Turn the pineapple upright and place a knife near the top edge. [5] X Expert Source Ed Kuoha Chef Expert Interview. 9 November 2021. Stand the pineapple so it's flat on your cutting board and hold it in place. Position a large knife at the top where the flat edge meets the side with the peel. [6] X Research source It doesn't matter which end of the pineapple is up or down.

steps.title: Cut down the side of the pineapple from top to bottom to remove a strip of the peel.
steps.content: Cut down the side of the pineapple from top to bottom to remove a strip of the peel. [7] X Expert Source Ed Kuoha Chef Expert Interview. 9 November 2021. Slowly move your knife back and forth to help it move down the pineapple. Try to cut the peel without removing too much fruit. [8] X Research source To keep the most fruit on the pineapple, remove about 1 ⁄ 4 inch (0.64 cm) off the sides.

steps.title: Slice the peel away from the entire pineapple.
steps.content: Slice the peel away from the entire pineapple. [9] X Expert Source Ed Kuoha Chef Expert Interview. 9 November 2021. Turn the pineapple a little so you can cut the peel away from another side of the pineapple. Continue to turn and slice off the peel until you've removed the whole thing. [10] X Research source Your pineapple is now peeled, but you'll see prickly eyes all over the fruit. Discard the pineapple peels or toss them in your compost .

steps.title: Look for the rows of eyes on the fruit.
steps.content: Look for the rows of eyes on the fruit. Keep your pineapple upright on the cutting board and look closely at the prickly eyes. You'll see that these eyes fall in diagonal lines, which will make them easy to trim away. [11] X Research source Although you could leave the eyes in the fruit, they can be unpleasantly prickly to eat.

steps.title: Cut a diagonal line next to a row of eyes.
steps.content: Cut a diagonal line next to a row of eyes. Take a small paring knife and cut into the pineapple's fruit at a 45-degree angle. Make a long diagonal cut next to 2 to 3 of the eyes. [12] X Research source You can cut above the eyes or below them.

steps.title: Slice another diagonal line on the opposite side of the eyes.
steps.content: Slice another diagonal line on the opposite side of the eyes. Move the paring knife so it's on the other side of the eyes and slice another line at a 45-degree angle. This will create a V-shaped trench with the eyes in the middle. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Pull away the eyes and discard them.
steps.content: Pull away the eyes and discard them. If the diagonal lines you cut intersect, the V-shaped piece of fruit with the eyes should be easy to remove. Use your finger to pull it out and away. [14] X Research source You can discard the strip of fruit with the eyes or trim the fruit between the eyes and save it.

steps.title: Continue to cut diagonal rows of eyes around the entire pineapple.
steps.content: Continue to cut diagonal rows of eyes around the entire pineapple. Cut another row of eyes below the row you just cut. Once you've cut away all the eyes from 1 side, turn the pineapple and cut all the eyes on that side. [15] X Research source The pineapple will begin to have a spiral shape from where you've removed the eyes.

steps.title: Cut
steps.content: Cut the pineapple into rings or wedges. To make rings, place the pineapple on its side and make slices as thick as you like. Use a small round cutter to slice out the tough center from each ring. If you'd rather cut wedges, cut the pineapple lengthwise into quarters. Then, cut out the tough core from the center of each wedge. [16] X Research source If you'd like to make chunks, take a wedge and slice crosswise to make pieces that are as wide as you want.
